awd_titl_txt: REU Site: A Summer Research Program that Integrates Deaf, Hearing and Sign Language Interpreting Participants to Advance Chemistry Research and to Enhance Science Communication
awd_abstract_narration:
This Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site award to James Madison University (JMU), located in Harrisonburg, VA, supports the training of 10 students for 10 weeks during the summers of 2018-2020. In this program, funded by the Division of Chemistry in the Mathematical and Physical Science Directorate, Professors Kevin Caran, Christine Hughey, and colleagues in the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry host an REU site that integrates deaf, hard of hearing (D/HH), and sign language-interpreting students in chemical research. JMU faculty members provide research opportunities in all major sub-disciplines of chemistry, with expertise centered in synthesis, biophysical chemistry and materials. In addition, students participate in a series of professional development activities aimed at enhancing effective science communication with other chemists, scientists in other disciplines, the public, and those with communication disorders (e.g. deaf and hard-of-hearing). Participants include students and faculty from JMU and outside institutions that serve deaf students or institutions that do not have extensive research infrastructure. By involving students in all aspects of the research process, from experimental design to dissemination of results, this program aims to lower the barriers, particularly for D/HH students, that hinder the pursuit of graduate studies in STEM fields.

The JMU Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry provides research opportunities for D/HH students and faculty. The students participate in a variety of research projects. Some examples include: the hydrogenation of carbon monoxide to formaldehyde, the development of hybrid materials for photovoltaic applications, and the use of molecular dynamics to elucidate the mechanisms of the binding of ubiquitin to its substrate protein. D/HH participants are supported with professional American Sign Language (ASL) interpreters and student interpreters in both professional and social settings. This immersive experience provides interpreting students the opportunity to learn and work in a science environment with the goal of developing professional interpreters with experience in the laboratory. In addition to the full-time student interpreters, additional ASL-interpreting students are invited to campus to observe the REU program for one week. The incorporation of these students expands the impact of the program by exposing a larger number of interpreting students to the challenges and opportunities involved in deaf communication in chemistry laboratories. All REU hearing participants, including faculty and students from outside colleges and universities, benefit from interactions with D/HH students and faculty, as hearing participants gain an appreciation for the challenges and opportunities associated with the inclusion of persons with disabilities. As a result of these interactions, this REU program aims to lower barriers for collaboration between these groups in the future.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The JMU Chemistry REU provides high quality summer research experiences for undergraduates, and meaningful opportunities for students to engage in science communication. The program includes support for Deaf and hard-of-hearing (D/HH) students and faculty, ASL (American Sign Language) student interpreters and their mentors, as well as outside students, primarily from schools that do not have extensive research instrumentation. A major goal of the JMU REU program is to integrate all students and provide them unique learning environment that may not be available in other REU programs. In particular, the incorporation of student interpreters provides valuable research and science-interpreting opportunities for the interpreting students while providing additional support for the deaf and hard-of-hearing participants.  The current award supported 28 REU students (including 6 student ASL-interpreters and 10 D/HH students), 4 external faculty members, and 6 additional ASL-student interpreting observers.  Student research from the REU program was presented at a variety of regional and national meetings and a total of 19 publications acknowledged support from this award.   

The NSF-REU program continues to provide a foundation upon which the summer research culture at JMU Chemistry & Biochemistry stands. Each summer, in addition to conducting chemistry research, students participated in a number of professional development activities, many of which focused on enhancing effective science communication.  These events included workshops on developing a professional elevator pitch, high quality figures and graphical abstracts. These science communication workshops were led by a variety of faculty and others with expertise in the area.  The ASL interpreting students ran a weekly “sign lunch” aimed at teaching both general and chemistry-specific signs to any interested students & faculty.  Deaf students also talked about Deaf culture and how hearing individuals should interact with D/HH individuals.  These science-communication and deaf culture events were open to (and well-attended by) all members of the department's summer research community. Each summer, this community averaged a ~50 undergraduate students per summer (>150 over three years), with the REU program providing an organizational foundation.  This significantly expands the reach of the work of the grant because it directly impacts many more students. Each of these individuals contributed to, participated in and benefitted from the research and scientific environment made possible by the program supported by NSF-REU.

The JMU REU Chemistry experience has also given the student ASL-interpreters a skill set in the field of science which most interpreters do not get in a general interpreter training program.  The hands-on interpreting work in the REU chemistry program has increased the participants' interpreting skills in the STEM field, and will be useful as they continue their progress toward their professional careers. In the future these students will be better equipped to interpret topics in science as a direct result of their REU experience, providing a STEM environment that is more accessible to Deaf and hard-of-hearing scientists.

The program has been successful in training both chemistry and ASL-interpreting students.  The ongoing work continues to break down barriers to collaboration between different groups of people by providing meaningful opportunities for Deaf, hard-of-hearing, and hearing individuals.
